replies.context:
The moon and the Earth are nearly identical in makeup, however in a collision between Earth and another planetoid, the heavy elements like iron would have been retained on Earth. And the heat produced during the impact and the ejection into space would have boiled the lighter elements off while the rest of the material would have mixed.
So if the difference is that the moon has less iron and less of the lighter elements such as hydrogen, the only water would be that that fell from comets.   It also has low gravity and next to no atmosphere, so surface water would sublimate into space unless hidden at the poles in shade.  The same lack of atmosphere results in extreme temperature variations and high radiation issues.

Or so the story goes....
Nonsense!! Why is it so hard to give credit where credit is due?
You question me not giving credit, yet you yourself question the outcome.  No faith?
There is much water in a frozen state on the moon. Most o which is stored underground. A planet with no atmosphere and massive temperature changes can not support live as we know it on earth.
